But to-day, for the first time in human history, our
technology includes an external projection of each of our senses.
Nobody has considered the significance of this development *4iich
confers on our technology an inclusive organic relation to man¬
kind for the first time. Prom the invention of the wheel and
alphabet onwards, we have been accustomed to conceive technol¬
ogy as a progressive splintering and dissociation of What in
nature is integral and organic. Thus the wheel was an abstraction
from animal form, since a running animal is In a sense rotating.
And the first movie ever made was of a running horse.
To-day radio, telegraph and T.V. have no moving parts.
The electronic age abandons mechanism for the movement of light
and information only. Viewed in the crudist quantitative terms,
the shift from mechanism to electronics presents tax* character
of total revolution. It is inconceivable that school and society
alike should not receive the full impact of this change.
Looked at more closely, the electronic mode of shaping
situations reveals its bias towards field structure, ait even
"field," preferred by physicists, can mislead by suggesting a
flat, single plane. But a multi-dimensional field is intended,
an "everyway roundabout with intrusions from above and below."
Thus, for example, "point-of-view," so inevitable in print culture,
is alien to electronic “field" and the affiliates of such "field."
